Name: Incorporating the audience
Description: Audience becomes part of the narrative.
Purpose: Increase empathy, facilitate personal comparisons. Helps make the data and information more personally relevant. To allow reader to use herself as measuring device.

Name: Repetition
Description: A phenomenon is re-presented multiple times with changes to the main variable/dimension (the data) or the time frame or the animation pattern (see the example) while other elements of the story don’t change. Note: this could be like running multiple simulations with the data to see which is most effective (and in this case, the story would be more reader driven)
Purpose: To show that the same phenomenon happens over and over again. It also strengthens the narrative through rhythm. Establishing a constant reference frame can help to emphasize change and differences.

Name: Juxtaposition
Description: Showing two or more complementary visualizations (pictures) juxtaposed.
Purpose: Compare cases or samples, allows to highlight contrast, difference, absense of difference, change over time. Allows for individual exploration of (minor) differences.

Name: Breaking the fourth wall
Description: Subject unexpectedly addresses the viewer.
Purpose: To make a direct connection with viewer; to demonstrate the artificiality of the presentation; to challenge the objectivity of the observation. To make it clear that this is one interpretation. Surprise, so attention-getting.
Additional contents:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fourth_wall

The fourth wall is the imaginary "wall" at the front of the stage in a traditional three-walled box set in a proscenium theatre, through which the audience sees the action in the world of the play.[1][2] The concept is usually attributed to the philosopher, critic and dramatist Denis Diderot.[3] The term itself was used by Molière.[4] The fourth wall illusion is often associated with naturalist theatre of the mid 19th-century, and especially with the innovations of the French director André Antoine.[4]

Name: Humans behind the dots
Description: Show that there are concrete entities (e.g., a human being) behind, or at the heart of the data.
Purpose: Make abstract data more relatable, and possibly establish an emotional connection between the viewer and the fate of the entities.

Name: Make a guess
Description: Enable the viewer to guess what insight they might find. If no interaction: interrupt the narrative with a question directly addressed to the viewer and provide the answer after. If interaction: promt the user with an entry form.
Purpose: Stimulates the viewer's curiosity, and possibly leads to a game-lke experience. To engage the reader in causal reasoning about the phenomenon.
Example title: You draw it — how family income affects childrens' college chances

Name: Rhetorical question
Description: Title the piece using a question that makes a point.
Purpose: Implicitely drives the viewer to the takeaway of a more open ended/exploratory piece.
Example title: Can you live on the minimum wage?
Additional contents: Not sure this is a good example. It's not a rhetocical question in the example.

Name: Familiar Setting
Description: Embed the entry point of a narrative in an environment which the viewer is familiar with.
Purpose: To lower the entry barrier and make information personally relatable.

Name: Call to action
Description: Start with presentation of problem that needs solving or situation that needs changing. End with call to action.
Purpose: Provides motivation; offers outline for narrative; gives sense of purpose.

Name: Gradual visual reveal
Description: Use visual hierarchy to control sequence of perception of individual elements
Purpose: Lets the story unfold in the viewer's mind while they read the graphic. to chunk the material to make it easier to absorb
Example title:
How Gun Traffickers Get
Around State Gun Laws

Name: Defamiliarization
Description: Present something known and familiar in a novel, unexpected way
Purpose: To confront and challenge viewers’ expectations; to highlight and question implicit assumptions. To force thinking differently about a well-known case.
Example title: Hobo-Dyer Equal Area Map, upside down
Additional contents: The term “defamiliarization” was first coined in 1917 by Viktor Shklovsky in his essay “Art as Device” (alternate translation: “Art as Technique”) . Shklovsky invented the term as a means to “distinguish poetic from practical language on the basis of the former’s perceptibility”. (source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defamiliarization)

Name: Convention breaking
Description: Use or establish a graphical convention, then break it.
Purpose: To engender surprise; to show extra-ordinary nature of data; to question the use of the convention; challenge assumptions.

Name: Speeding up
Description: Increase speed over time
Purpose: To give the feeling of acceleration, increased momentum, urgency. To transition from the individual to the group; to surprise with change in perspective; to exploit the learned interpretation of the early slow depictions.

Name: Concretize
Description: Isotype. Provide known, concrete reference frame
Purpose: Make it easier to get a grasp on large, otherwise abstract numbers. To increase memorability.
Example title: US Debt Ceiling Visualized in $100 Bills

Name: Users find themselves
Description: Device used to help anchor the viewer in the piece.
Purpose: Helps make the data and information more personally relevant. To allow reader to use herself as measuring device.
Example title: Which sport would work for you?

Name: Meaningful use of space
Description: Use space and direction of movement to reinforce positive or negative feelings. Frequently, up = good; down = bad; left = retreat; right = progress.
Purpose: To support metaphor; to allow viewer to construct their own metaphor more easily; to take advantage of convention to ease understanding.
Example title: How China’s economic slowdown could weigh on the rest of the world.

Name: Silent data
Description: The deliberate choice of not showing (hiding) certain data (like pauses in music?)
Purpose: emphasizing aspects with de-emphasizing some data
Additional contents: Talk at OpenVisConf 2014: "The design of nothing": http://www.visualisingdata.com/2014/04/talk-slides-from-openvisconf-2014-the-design-of-nothing/

Name: Switch from mimesis to diegesis
Description: Switch visual emphasis from text to chart and vice-versa, either when a chart is only used as an illustration of the text, or when the text is only used to annotate the chart.
Purpose: Helps the viewer detect what the main source of information is, i.e., the text or the graphic.

Name: Dark Inversion
Description: [Term from Christopher Booker's 'The Seven Basic Plots'] "An honourable man turns bad". Rather than seeing a protagonist develop over a story emerging transformed as a better person, we see the opposite. Honour is gradually corrupted over the lifetime of the story. (e.g. Hamlet, Breaking Bad, The Godfather etc.)
Purpose:
To evoke a strong emotional response to seeing loss of ideal, corruption of intent etc.[I have an idea to illustrate this: Bar chart of different nations' pledges for international aid. Rather than simply contrast those figures with actual aid donated (which is considerably less in many cases), we see those bars 'crumble' to their new lower height. We make the corruption of the ideal explicit in graphical terms. Can use ideas similar to 'sanddance' and visual sedimentation

[I have an idea to illustrate this: Bar chart of different nations' pledges for international aid. Rather than simply contrast those figures with actual aid donated (which is considerably less in many cases), we see those bars 'crumble' to their new lower height. We make the corruption of the ideal explicit in graphical terms. Can use ideas similar to 'sanddance' and visual sedimentation

Name: The Columbo howdunit
Description: Present outcome first, then structure narrative around how we arrived at the outcome.
Purpose: To focus on process not outcome; to emphasise causality and explanation.

Name: Redefine perspective
Description: start depiction at one scale until then rapidly or unexpectedly change scale.
Purpose: Emphasise difference in magnitude; to demonstrate the irrelevance of small change; to surprise;
Example title:
Charles and Ray Eames, Powers of Ten http://www.eamesoffice.com/the-work/powers-of-ten/

 http://www.gicentre.net/blog/2013/11/24/risk-cycling-and-denominator-neglect

Name: The antagonist
Description: Two opposite “versions” of the story are represented, pushing the user to position herself (choose one of them) or creating a tension between the two poles. The title can help in reinforcing the rhetorics, by using for example “vs.” or “this or that”
Purpose:
Asking the user to take a position or at least to compare the two “versions” forces a deeper understanding of the data and can more easily lead to a conclusion.

(warning!) the opposition could lead the user to take a position a-priori, ideologically, not based on the data.

Name: Argumentation/debate
Description: Engage user in dialogue with opposing views/conclusions
Purpose: promote critical evaluation of alternatives
Example title: Different headlines for same data (unemployment projections?) - story, still looking for vis

Name: The weight of tension
Description: Put the weight of the built up tension on the shoulders of the viewer
Purpose: To leave a lasting impression; to motivate progression in the narrative

Name: Difficult moral choice
Description: Solomon’s choice
Purpose: Evaluation of tradeoffs; to make abstract real.

Name: Flatter the audience
Example title: Which sport would work for you?

Name: The quest
Description: Statement of clear goal, document of how barriers were overcome to achieve it.
Purpose: Provides motivation for advancing the narrative; signals an end point to the narrative;

Name: Level up
Description: Using gaming approaches, over time, reveal new elements of the visualization (could be new representation or new interaction possibilities)
Purpose: To provide a motivation to continue; to give sense of reward; to ease the introduction of complexity.
column16: Passing record holders on the One Year Time Trial http://gicentre.org/oytt/

Name: Enactment / performance / histrionic / physical echo of data space
Description: Human narrator uses body language to reinforce spatial mapping of data space.
Purpose: Embeds abstract idea in real space; repetition for emphasis;

Name: Make the user work
Description: The more people invest, the more valuable the result becomes
Example title: ?possibly the payoff at the end of this post? : http://www.gicentre.net/blog/2013/11/24/risk-cycling-and-denominator-neglect (the ‘work’ here is in the scrolling to the bottom, not necessarily intellectual work).

Name: Sherlock Holmes
Description: Put the the user in the investigator’s shoes. Note (Jeremy): this could be like the Again and Again if it is delivered as a simulation platform
Purpose: To encourage deductive thinking; to generate a sense of ownership of the findings on the part of the viewer; to set an explicit purpose.

Name: The journey
Description: Focus on a single subject but change its surroundings.
Purpose: Emphasises common connections between apparently different scenarios; anchor change to ease understanding when showing new perspectives.

Name: Freeze frame
Description: Stopping or slowing down of the rate at which new data are presented.
Purpose: To place focus on a particular aspect of the story; to encourage reflection;

Name: Stepwise reveal
Description: Explicit stepwise reveal, e.g. through paging, animated transitions

Name: Unreliable narrator
Description: Contradictions or increasing lack of credibility in depiction emerges slowly forcing viewer to question the reliability of what they see.
Purpose: To encourage critical evaluation; to demonstrate lack of objectivity in depiction; to surprise.
Example title:
Maybe by highlighting shortcomings of the data?

Not quite visualization (although visual): http://www.mcsweeneys.net/articles/an-interactive-guide-to-ambiguous-grammar (do read from top down to the very end).

Name: Change of visual perspective
Description: Zoom, pan, …
Purpose: To draw attention to specific details.

Name: The Reveal
Alt. title: Hold back a critical part of the story to add impact when it is revealed.
Description: To evoke surprise and emphasise the point of the reveal
Purpose: Example PDF shows data that could be used (although the presentation does not use 'reveal' in this case). Could show the data for all EU states first (horizontal black lines in PDF), then show the variation (blue bars) and capital cities (red dots) for all nations except the UK. The 'reveal' would be in showing the UK figures with such a higher variation in GDP by region than all other states. Even Luxembourg which we might have originally believed to be the extreme outlier until the reveal.

Name: What if?
Alt. title: Explore imaginative scenarios with data ("What if there was no taxation?"; "What if global temperature was to rise by 4 degrees?" etc.)
Description: By using extremes, it is easier to make more subtle scenarios salient
